post.body:
Hi from Japan!
日本からこんにちは

Needless to say I disapprove the terrible riots in Washington, but I'm also certainly disappointed in the fact the big platforms finally get no other choice but to ban Trump.
As we're often told, a real human sits behind an account on the platform. Especially these days, when we have to rely on such social media platforms, what do we find out the differences between banning his account from a platform and shooting him to death in a convention (even if he was given a warning).
Recognize the era of speech came to an end, and that we've entered an era of force by word.
And severely beware life or death both of ourselves and of our accounts is always under control of the centralized platforms.

**Protips for people blindly supporting Facebook, Twitter, AWS...**

First they came for Trump, and you didn't speak out—
  Because you were not a Patriot.

Then they came for you—and there's no one left to speak for you.

An attempt to decentralize is simply interesting for me, makes us excited, and is wanted to spread and continue over the world. Doesn't matter it is correct in a manner of some standard (e.g. politically).

comment.body: Some of the guys, including me, assumed he's spamming, but actually he tried to find word limit on ZeroMe.
Very easy... if you remember 46 hiraganas, 46 katakanas, and about 2000 kanjis lol
@mxh69420: I might not be sure what you mean for "spelling it out with letters", but the Japanese people regularly use ひらがな(hiraganas), カタカナ(katakanas), and 漢字(kanjis) when we write something.

**Protips:** In everyday life, about 3,000 kanjis are used, while a "professional" kanji user surely know 6,000 ones since such amount of ones are required to pass the top level of *kanji kentei* (The Japan Kanji Aptitude Test). And some kanji dictionary contain 50,000+ kanjis. The total number of kanjis is, it's accurately unknown though, said to be over 100,000.
I don't know as for Chinese kanjis, that are different from Japanese ones, although the latter originates in the former.
@mxh69420: Exactly. Most of the Japanese people use romaji input system when entering text into a computer.
